thread.title: Tasmanian loos with views: Taking care of toilets for bushwalkers answering the call of nature - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Tasmanian loos with views: Taking care of toilets for bushwalkers answering the call of nature - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Abc Radio Hobart
title: Tasmanian loos with views: Taking care of toilets for bushwalkers answering the call of nature - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: TAS 
When you are out and about in nature, you still need to answer its call from time to time. 
Parks and Wildlife look after about 330 toilets in some of the most remote and difficult places to get to in Tasmania. External Link: Toilet at Prion Beach 
Matt McCormick from Parks and Wildlife spends his days replacing, maintaining and building toilets in some very out-of-the-way places. 
"A lot of them can be in remote areas that are not as easy to service as what you commonly see in urban parks," he told Helen Shield on ABC Radio Hobart . 
Recently Mr McCormick and the Parks and Wildlife team replaced a toilet at Lake Geeves in Southwest National Park. 
While it may not be the remotest toilet in terms of kilometres, it is one of the hardest places to get to according to Mr McCormick. 
"I think because of where it is, it's possibly the hardest to get to. 
"It's a fantastic spot and it's a well-earned location once you get there, but I must say, it is one of the most difficult and remote walks we have in Tasmania. 
"It's really for the most capable of outback country walkers."
